subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] New Zealand dialect
msgSnippet: ... Hi Paige, If nothing else, our work will help clarify the use of QS. I pretty much agree with your point on beer and bear, but some mergers may present
messageBody:
C. Paige Gabhart wrote:
>
>
> Tony:
>
> I appreciate all the time that has been spent in developing the use of
> these lexical sets. I will say that to some extent I see this as an
> attempt by group members who are quite new to QS to work out what they
> see as a problem. I believe Moira commented that different accents are
> not as much of a problem as you seem to believe and her assertion is
> proven by the letter writing campaign in QS that went on 30 years or
> more ago. For example, I have letters written in 1975 by a New
> Zealander. I can't remember having any trouble reading his QS.
>
> If Paul pronounces bear and beer the same, it just means his QS will
> have two homonyms that most people's dialect doesn't. Surely, the
> difference will come out in context. "I love a cold bear after cutting
> the grass" is hardly open to much confusion although it might cause a
> smile among those of us who don't merge those two sounds.
>

Hi Paige,

If nothing else, our work will help clarify the use of QS.

I pretty much agree with your point on beer and bear, but some mergers
may present more of a problem. However, I am really interested in
tackling this issue in a more concrete way at this point, so your input
would be very helpful. If you could illustrate how different words in NZ
appeared in your correspondances and how they didn't hinder
communication, we might see how QS has handled different dialects in
practice, which would be enlightening. I know you don't have every
single letter you ever wrote or received, but any hints in this
direction still could help.

Paul

PS What happened to our fall, neighbor? I was only able to keep my
windows open about 3 days in six months.
